leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.25] r 14.25 Defence of tender (cf SCR Part 15, rule 24; DCR Part 10, rule 1A; LCR Part 9, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Defence of tender (cf SCR Part 15, rule 24; DCR Part 10, rule 1A; LCR Part 9, rule 1)

p.text: If, in proceedings on a liquidated claim, a defence of tender before commencement of the proceedings is pleaded, the tender is not available as a defence unless and until the amount has been paid into court.
In the case of a tender to which section 224 of the Customs Act 1901 of the Commonwealth applies:
subrule (1) does not apply to a defence that pleads the tender, and
the amount tendered may be paid into court when the defence is filed.
On paying the money into court, the defendant must file notice of the payment into court and serve the notice on each other party to the proceedings.
The plaintiff may accept the money by filing a notice of acceptance.
If the plaintiff accepts the money, the proceedings are to be stayed in relation to the defence of tender.
Whether or not accepted, the money must not be paid out except by order of the court.

Tender before the commencement of proceedings is a good defence to an action to recover a debt and payment into court is an integral part of the defence: Griffıths v Ystradyfodwg School Board (1890) 24 QBD 307; 62 LT 151Â ; The Mona [1894] P 265; Bonitto v Fuerst Bros & Co Ltd [1944] AC 75; [1944] 1 All ER 91Â . The proffering of cash or its equivalent in the full amount constitutes a valid tender: Australian Mid-Eastern Club Ltd v Yassim (1989) 1 ACSR 399 at 403; 8 ACLC 46; BC8901303Â ; Burnham v Carroll Musgrave Theatres Ltd (1928) 41 CLR 540 at 558; 2 ALJR 279Â . If the defence is established the plaintiff will be ordered to pay the costs of the proceedings. A defence of tender that is not accompanied by payment into court is liable to be struck out: Busch v Anderson [1905] QWN 42Â ; although payment in is not required in the case of an equitable plea of tender: Neville v Hansen (1899) 5 ALR 230Â . Tender cannot be pleaded as a defence to a claim for unliquidated damages: Davys v Richardson (1888) 21 QBD 202Â ; Mitchellmore v Salomon (1909) 1 Tas LR 39.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.26] r 14.26 Admission and traverse from pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 20, Part 63, rule 9; DCR Part 9, rule 14, Part 45, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Admission and traverse from pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 20, Part 63, rule 9; DCR Part 9, rule 14, Part 45, rule 9)

p.text: An allegation of fact made by a party in a pleading is taken to be admitted by any opposite party required to plead in response unless:
in the pleading in response, the opposite party traverses the allegation, or
a joinder of issues under rule 14.27 operates as a denial of the allegation.
A traverse may be made by denial or by a statement of non-admission, either expressly or by necessary implication, and either generally or as to any particular allegation.

Despite subrule (1), a pleading in response to a pleading that alleges the suffering of damage or an amount of damages is taken to traverse the allegation unless it specifically admits the allegation.
Subrule (1) does not apply to an opposite party who is a person under a legal incapacity.
[subr (4) subst Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[12], effective 8 December 2006]
Legislation cited in [14.26.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 14.26(3).

The deemed traverse provided for in rÂ 14.26(3) applies to damage of all kinds whether special or general and whether the alleged damage is part of the cause of action or not: Wilby v Elston (1849) 8 CB 142; 137 ER 462Â ; Fovear v Sinclair (1917) 33 TLR 318 at 319. A plaintiff may plead matters in aggravation of damages: Millington v Loring (1880) 6 QBD 190Â ; Whitney v Moignard (1890) 24 QBD 630Â . As to defamation proceedings, see Plato Films Ltd v Speidel [1961] AC 1090; [1961] 1 All ER 876Â .

As a matter of practice, parties should admit facts in respect of which there is no real dispute: Lee Conservancy Board v Button (1879) 12 Ch D 383Â . Where a party refuses to make appropriate admissions, they may be ordered to pay any costs incurred by unnecessary denials or improper refusals to admit. An implied admission under this rule has the same effect as an express admission: Byrd v Nunn (1877) 5 Ch D 781Â ; Green v Sevin (1879) 13 Ch D 589Â ; Collette v Goode (1878) 7 Ch D 842Â . However, in order to gain the advantage of an implied admission under the rule, the relevant allegation must be clear and precise: Ash v Hutchinson & Co (Publishers) Ltd [1936] Ch 489; [1936] 2 All ER 1496Â ; and in an appropriate case an admission which is unwarily made may be permitted to be withdrawn: Hollis v Burton [1892] 3 Ch 226Â . Particulars do not constitute separate allegations of fact and therefore no implied admission is made by a failure to traverse matters raised in particulars, even where the particulars have been set out in the body of the pleading: Chapple v Electrical Trades Union [1961] 3 All ER 612; [1961] 1 WLR 1290Â .

In order to gain the advantage of an implied admission under this rule, a pleading must be clear and precise: Ash v Hutchinson & Co (Publishers) Ltd [1936] Ch 489; [1936] 2 All ER 1496Â . But if the allegation satisfies that requirement, an implied admission made by a failure to traverse has the same effect as an express admission: Byrd v Nunn (1877) 5 Ch D 781Â ; Byrd v Nunn (1877) 7 Ch D 284Â ; Green v Sevin (1879) 13 Ch D 589Â ; Colette v Goode (1878) 7 Ch D 842Â .

level.toc-caption: [14.26.20] Denial, non-admission and the sufficiency of traverse

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.26.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR rÂ 14.23, UCPR r 14.26(2).

heading.title: Denial, non-admission and the sufficiency of traverse

p.text: The implied admission arising from a failure to traverse only applies to pleaded factual allegations. Particulars included in a pleading are merely an outline of evidentiary matters. They are not themselves allegations requiring specific traverse: Chapple v Electrical Trades Union [1961] 3 All ER 612; [1961] 1 WLR 1290Â .

A sufficient traverse may be made by either denial or non-admission. There is no difference between the practical effect of a denial on the one hand and non-admission on the other: Hall v London & North Western Railway (1877) 35 LT 848Â ; Warner v Sampson [1959] 1 QB 297 at 319; [1959] 1 All ER 120Â . A denial is usually employed where the disputed fact is within a party’s knowledge. A statement of non-admission commonly indicates that the disputed fact is not within the party’s knowledge. Different forms of verification are required under UCPR rÂ 14.23 depending upon which of these two traverses has been employed. Because of the content of the verification required by rÂ 14.23, a defendant ought properly to admit facts as to which there is no real dispute: Lee Conservancy Board v Button (1879) 12 Ch D 383Â ; Fox v H Wood (Harrow) Ltd [1963] 2 QB 601; [1962] 3 All ER 1100Â (no particulars will be ordered of any such admission).

UCPR r 14.26(2) contemplates that a sufficient traverse may be made by “necessary implication”: Rockcote Enterprises Pty Ltd v FS Architects Pty Ltd (No 2) [2008] NSWCA 205; BC200807789 at [12] [20], [1] and [59]Â (internal inconsistency in the pleading ). Whilst this suggests a responsive pleading should not be interpreted pedantically, it is highly desirable that any traverse of the allegations in the statement of claim is clearly made: Gordon v Gordon [1948] VLR 57 at 58; [1948] 1 ALR 24Â . That clear traverse should take the form of a specific denial or non-admission. A statement that a party “does not plead to” a particular allegation in a pleading is neither a denial, nor a statement of non-admission and it may, depending on the nature of the allegation itself (and assuming no material inconsistency, with other pleaded traverses) constitute a formal admission in the proceedings: Rockcote Enterprises Pty Ltd v FS Architects Pty Ltd; Carelli v FS Architects Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 39; BC200801968 at [62] [63]Â per Campbell JA, at [1] per McColl JA and at [128] per Handley AJA agreeing. However, whether such an admission means that there was no issue on the pleadings about the matters thereby admitted, may depend upon whether there are related paragraphs that have been pleaded to and the pleading as a whole.

Leave is required to withdraw any admissions made in the proceedings, including admissions deemed to have been made as a result of the absence of an adequate traverse under the present rule: see generally [17.2.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.27] r 14.27 Joinder of issue (cf SCR Part 15, rule 21; DCR Part 9, ruleÂ 15Â

leg:heading.title: Joinder of issue (cf SCR Part 15, rule 21; DCR Part 9, ruleÂ 15Â

p.text: A pleading may expressly join issue on a previous pleading.
If there is no reply by a plaintiff to a defence, there is an implied joinder of issue on that defence.
If there is no answer by the opposite party to a reply or subsequent pleading, there is an implied joinder of issue on the reply or subsequent pleading.
There can be no joinder of issue, express or implied, on a statement of claim.
An implied joinder of issue on a pleading operates as a denial of every allegation of fact made in the pleading.
An express joinder of issue on a pleading operates as a denial of every allegation of fact made in the pleading other than an allegation that is expressly admitted.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.28] r 14.28 Circumstances in which court may strike out pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 26; DCR Part 9, rule 17; LCR Part 8, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Circumstances in which court may strike out pleadings (cf SCR Part 15, rule 26; DCR Part 9, rule 17; LCR Part 8, rule 3)

p.text: The court may at any stage of the proceedings order that the whole or any part of a pleading be struck out if the pleading:
discloses no reasonable cause of action or defence or other case appropriate to the nature of the pleading, or
has a tendency to cause prejudice, embarrassment or delay in the proceedings, or
is otherwise an abuse of the process of the court.
The court may receive evidence on the hearing of an application for an order under subrule (1).
Legislation cited in [14.28.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 13.4.

Every court has, as a necessary incident of its jurisdiction, the power to control its own proceedings and procedure: Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [6]Â ; Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380 at 393; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073Â (asset preservation orders); CSR Ltd v Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 345 at 391; 146 ALR 402; [1997] HCA 33; BC9703378Â (anti-suit injunction). The power can be exercised to strike out proceedings that constitute an abuse of process: see also rÂ 13.4 of the UCPR. The concept of abuse of process overlaps other specific rules that justify the striking out of proceedings or pleadings. It involves wider considerations than mere non-compliance with rules, orders or directions. Proceedings conducted within the literal application of the formal rules may, nevertheless, constitute an abuse of process: Hunter v Chief Constable of the West Midlands Police [1982] AC 529 at 536; [1981] 3 All ER 727Â ; Castanho v Brown & Root (UK) Ltd [1981] AC 557 at 571; [1981] 1 All ER 143Â (filing a notice of discontinuance). The width of the concept defies any exhaustive categorisation of the types of proceedings that may constitute an abuse of process, but certain illustrative categories have been recognised and include the following:

futility: proceedings that are doomed to fail — either because they disclose no cause of action or because of events that have occurred since their commencement: Domer v Gulf Oil (Great Britain) Ltd (1975) 119 Sol Jo 392Â ; or because the proceedings are untenable in the known or admitted circumstances: Charles Forte Investments Ltd v Amanda [1964] Ch 240; [1963] 2 All ER 940Â ; Mann v Goldstein [1968] 2 All ER 769 at 771; [1968] 1 WLR 1091 at 1093Â ; Bryanston Finance Ltd v De Vries (No 2) [1976] Ch 63 at 76, 79; [1976] 1 All ER 25Â ; Australian Mid Eastern Club Ltd v Elbakht (1988) 13 NSWLR 697; 14 ACLR 234Â (cases of attempts to use the non-payment of bona fide disputed debts as a ground for a winding up petition); Ruffıno v Grace Bros Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 732Â (the plaintiff had already obtained a satisfied judgment against a concurrent tortfeasor); Moriarty v London Chatham and Dover Railway Co (1870) LR 5 QB 314 (plaintiff had admitted the absence of a cause of action). (Although no abuse of process is involved in commencing proceedings by issuing “holding writs”, even though they contain allegations (including of fraud) that could not immediately be sustained: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1995) 57 FCR 360Â and Dowling v Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society Ltd (1915) 20 CLR 509; 21 ALR 425; [1915] HCA 56Â );

delay: proceedings that cannot be fairly and properly determined — because of prejudicial delay since the events to which the proceedings relate: Jago v District Court of New South Wales (1989) 168 CLR 23; 87 ALR 577; BC8902707Â ; Clyne v New South Wales Bar Assn (1960) 104 CLR 186 at 201; [1960] ALR 574; BC6000600Â ; Berger v Raymond Sun Ltd [1984] 1 WLR 625Â (unduly prolonging a trial); Connelly v DPP [1964] AC 1254; [1964] 2 WLR 1145Â ; Herron v McGregor (1986) 6 NSWLR 246 at 251Â ; Walton v Gardiner (1993) 177 CLR 378 at 395; 112 ALR 289; BC9303612Â (stay of disciplinary proceedings in the Medical Tribunal on the ground of unacceptable injustice or unfairness arising out of prolonged delay); Batistatos v RTA of NSW (2006) 227 ALR 425; [2006] HCA 27; BC200604226 at [8]Â (plaintiff under disability — proceedings commenced after 29Â years — abuse of process);

duplication: proceedings involving claims that have already been determined and are res judicata: Bayne v Blake (No 3) (1909) 9 CLR 366; [1909] HCA 60Â . See also Clarke v Darley (1898) 14 WN (NSW) 129Â ; Hall v Johnson (1904) 29 VLR 649; 10 ALR 87Â ; Petree v Knox (1918) 35 WN (NSW) 32Â ; Ayoub vÂ Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd [2011] NSWSC 606; BC201104489Â (claim repeating allegations in cross-claim dismissed in earlier proceedings) and see [14.28.15] and [14.28.17] ;

destruction of evidence: proceedings that cannot be fairly and properly determined — because of the deliberate destruction of material evidence: Clark v NSW [2012] NSWCA 139; BC201203424Â (destruction of material evidence after adjournment of proceedings — abuse of process — related causes of action dismissed); Palavi v Radio 2UE Sydney Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 264; BC201106918Â (destruction of mobile phones by plaintiff in defamation proceedings in defiance of order for discovery where discovery was likely to provide substantial evidentiary assistance to defendant — abuse of process); Clark vÂ NSW [2012] NSWCA 139; BC201203424 atÂ [84]–[108]Â (destruction of tape recording — critical conversation — evidence material to both claim and defence — related causes of action struck out); British American Tobacco Australia Services Ltd v Cowell (2003) 8 VR 571; [2003] VSCA 43; BC200301919Â (documents destroyed before commencement of proceedings — no abuse of process); Fuji Xerox Australia Pty Ltd v Lee [2003] QSC 303; BC200305342Â (machine destroyed before commencement of proceedings — no abuse of process);

fabricated evidence: proceedings that cannot be fairly and properly determined — because of the risk of fabrication of evidence: Arrow Nominees Inc v Blackledge [2000] All ER (D) 854; [2000] 2 BCLC 167; [2000] EWCA Civ 200Â (provision of forged documents on discovery — proceedings dismissed);

previously determined issues: proceedings involving substantially the same point as a matter decided in former proceedings and where it would be unfair to permit it to be raised afresh: Hunter v Chief Constable of the West Midlands Police [1982] AC 529; [1981] 3 All ER 727Â (civil claim made inconsistent with a prior criminal conviction); Rogers v R (1994) 181 CLR 251 at 255, 287; 123 ALR 417; BC9404645Â (attempt to rely upon admissions held involuntary, and consequently inadmissible, in previous proceedings); Rippon v Chilcotin Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 198; [2001] NSWCA 142; BC200103792Â (attempt to relitigate an adverse causation finding made in previous proceedings against a concurrent tortfeasor); Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs v Gungor (1982) 42 ALR 209; 63 FLR 441Â (claim in administrative proceedings involving a claim challenging the factual basis of a prior criminal conviction); R vÂ Carroll (2002) 213 CLR 635; 194 ALR 1; [2002] HCA 55; BC200207276Â (prosecution for perjury after acquittal on principal offence); McIlkenny vÂ Chief Constable of West Midlands Police Force [1980] QB 283 at 322; [1980] 2 All ER 227; [1980] 2 WLR 689Â (assault claim by the convicted “Birmingham six” — assault issue adversely decided at the criminal trial in ruling confessional evidence voluntary — civil claim an abuse of process); State Bank of New South Wales Ltd vÂ Alexander Stenhouse Ltd (1997) Aust Torts Reports 81-423; BC9700254 (claim for “fault” indemnity for “unjust enrichment” liability found in proceedings to which insurer not a party — no abuse of process); Cleary v Jeans (2006) 65 NSWLR 355; [2006] NSWCA 9; BC200600482Â (collateral attack on an earlier decision involving the same issue or issues but not necessarily involving the same parties); Five D v Impact Building [2007] NSWSC 993; BC200707680Â (proceedings summarily dismissed for the same reason); Solak v Registrar of Titles [2009] VSC 614; BC200911553Â (mortgagor’s liability conclusively determined in previous proceedings between mortgagor and mortgagee);

plaintiff in default: proceedings commenced after unremedied default in prior incomplete proceedings for substantially the same cause of action: Andrew v Baradom Holdings Pty Ltd (in liq) (1995) 36 NSWLR 700; 17 ACSR 231; BC9504567Â (earlier proceedings struck out as a result of a deliberate failure to comply with directions).

level.toc-caption: [14.28.10] Abuse of process — use of proceedings for an improper purpose

heading.title: Abuse of process — use of proceedings for an improper purpose

p.text: It is clearly an abuse of process to use “Court proceedings... for the purpose of obtaining... some collateral advantage... and a party so using or threatening proceedings will be liable to be held guilty of abusing the process of the court and therefore disqualified from invoking the powers of the court by proceedings he has abused”: Re Majory [1955] Ch 600 at 623–4Â per Evershed MR; Williams v Spautz (1992) 174 CLR 509; 107 ALR 635; BC9202694Â ; Spautz v Williams [1983] 2 NSWLR 506 at 539Â ; Flower & Hart (a firm) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd (1999) 87 FCR 134; 163 ALR 744; [1999] FCA 773; BC9903036Â ; see also Castro v Murray (1875) LR 10 Ex 213; Dawkins v Prince Edward (1886) 11 P 59 at 63; King v Henderson (1897) 3 ALR (CN) 12; 13 WN (NSW) 137Â ; Re Septimus Parsonage and Co [1901] 2 Ch 424Â ; Bayne v Baillieu (1908) 6 CLR 382; 14 ALR 426Â ; Dowling v Colonial Mutual Life Assurance Society Ltd (1915) 20 CLR 509; 21 ALR 425; [1915] HCA 56Â ; Goldsmith v Sperrings Ltd [1977] 2 All ER 566; [1977] 1 WLR 478Â ; Varawa v Howard Smith & Co Ltd (1911) 13 CLR 35 at 91Â . But proceedings may constitute an abuse of process if they are being prosecuted for any improper purpose, irrespective of whether or not that purpose is “collateral” in the ordinary sense of that term. The essential question for determination is whether or not the proceedings, or the particular claims made in them, are genuinely intended to be determined in the proceedings: Flower & Hart (a firm) v White Industries (Qld) Pty Ltd, above. According to this criterion, proceedings may be categorised as having an improper purpose, even if the moving party has a prima facie case, or must be assumed to have such a case: Grovit v Doctor [1997] 2 All ER 417; [1997] 1 WLR 640Â (commencement and continuation of proceedings with no intention of bringing them to a conclusion is an abuse of process irrespective of whether the defendant has been prejudiced by the delay); Berger v Raymond Sun Ltd [1984] 1 WLR 625Â (unduly prolonging a trial); Westpac Banking Corp v Northern Metals Pty Ltd (1989) 14 IPR 499; (1989) ATPR Â¶40-953Â (alternative claim struck out as embarrassing where its only purpose was to obtain wider discovery).

level.toc-caption: [14.28.12] Abuse of process — improper termination of proceedings

heading.title: Abuse of process — improper termination of proceedings

p.text: The concept of abuse of process can also extend to include conduct involved in bringing the proceedings to an end: Castanho v Brown & Root (UK) Ltd [1981] AC 557 at 571; [1981] 1 All ER 143Â (filing a notice of discontinuance); Packer v Meagher [1984] 3 NSWLR 486Â (filing a notice of discontinuance without leave) and Clyne v DCT (1984) 154 CLR 589; 55 ALR 143; BC8400473Â ; TJM Products Pty Ltd v A & P Tyres Pty Ltd (1987) 17 FCR 390; 78 ALR 579Â (entry of judgment set aside as an abuse of process when entry made for the purpose of depriving the court of jurisdiction to deal with a pending application to vary a costs order following final judgment).

Proceedings will be struck out if the cause of action sought to be raised has actually been determined in earlier proceedings and is “res judicata”: Ord v Ord [1923] 2 KB 432Â ; Hoystead v Cmr of Taxation [1926] C 155; Bradford and Bingley Building Society v Sneddon [1999] 4 All ER 217 at 225; [1999] 1 WLR 1482 at 1490Â ; MacDougall v Knight (1890) 25 QBD 1Â ; Stephenson v Garnett [1898] 1 QB 677 at 682Â ; Langmead v Maple (1865) 18 CBNS 225 at 270; 144 ER 441; Barr v Jackson (1842) 1 Y & C Ch Cas 585; 62 ER 1028; This principle applies even if the prior judgment was made by consent: Palmer v Dunford Ford (a firm) [1992] 1 QB 483 at 489; [1992] 2 All ER 122Â .

Proceedings will also be regarded as an abuse of process to the extent that they involve an attempt to relitigate particular issues that were determined, either explicitly or necessarily, in earlier judicial proceedings (including proceedings determined by consent). Such a determination gives rise to “issue estoppel”: Blair & Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Curran (Adam’s will) (1939) 62 CLR 464Â ; Noall v Middleton [1961] VR 285Â ; Commissioner for Railways v Bielewicz [1963] NSWR 482 at 486; [1963] SR (NSW) 466 at 468Â ; Carl Ziess Stiftung v Rayner (No 3) [1970] Ch 506; [1969] 3 WLR 991Â . Issue estoppel may also apply to determinations by some state administrative tribunals: Lambidis v Cmr of Police (1995) 37 NSWLR 320 at 331–2; BC9505273Â (though probably not to determinations by federal administrative tribunals: Miller v University of New South Wales (2003) 132 FCR 147; 200 ALR 565; [2003] FCAFC 180; BC200304515 at [9] and [48]–[74]Â ; Badraie v Commonwealth [2005] NSWSC 1195; BC200510045Â ). The scope of the estoppel is confined to those issues that were directly involved in the actual decision made in the previous proceeding (and does not include every finding that was made): Murphy v Abi-Saab (1995) 37 NSWLR 280; BC9505070Â . Where the basis for “issue estoppel” has been made out, the court retains an overriding discretion to permit the proceedings to continue, although this discretion is likely to be exercised only in exceptional circumstances: Arnold v National Westminster Bank plc [1991] 2 AC 93; [1991] 3 All ER 41Â ; Johnson v Gore Wood and Co (a firm) [2002] 2 AC 1 at 30; [2001] 1 All ER 481 at 498Â per BinghamÂ LJ.

A “wider” or “ancillary” sense of the doctrine of res judicata was recognised by the High Court in Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun Pty Ltd (1981) 147 CLR 589; 36 ALR 3; BC8100097Â . Variously referred to as “Anshun estoppel”, the “extended principle in Henderson v Henderson [1843-60] All ER Rep 378; (1843) 67 ER 313Â ”; and the “wider” or “ancillary” sense of the doctrine of res judicata (Yat Tung Investment Co Ltd v Dao Heng Bank Ltd [1975] AC 581 at 590; [1975] 2 WLR 690 at 696Â ; Johnson v Gore Wood and Co (a firm) [2002] 2 AC 1 at 59B; [2001] 1 All ER 481 at 525Â ), the principle is that parties must bring forward all material matters for determination in the proceedings, meaning that the parties cannot raise in subsequent proceedings matters that could, and should reasonably, have been raised in earlier proceedings. The Anshun principle applies even though the matter was not essential to the determination of the earlier proceedings, and consequently is not barred by either the doctrine of res judicata or issue estoppel in the strict sense. It can apply where the earlier proceedings ended in compromise rather than formal judgment: Johnson v Gore Wood and Co (a firm) , above. Further, a claim that could have been raised in earlier (concluded) proceedings and which, if allowed, would lead to inconsistent judgments, may be barred under this principle: Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun , above (failure to plead a contractual indemnity in defence to a claim for tortfeasor contribution); Chamberlain v DCT (ACT) (1988) 164 CLR 502; 78 ALR 271; BC8802663Â ; Tanning Research Laboratories Inc v O’Brien (1990) 169 CLR 332 at 346; 91 ALR 180; BC9002954Â ; Heid v Connell Investments Pty Ltd (1989) 16 NSWLR 629Â ; Ergi v DRG Australia Ltd (1988) 19 NSWLR 600Â ; Boles v Esanda Finance Corp Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 666Â ; Australian Energy Ltd v Lennard Oil NL (No 2) [1988] Qd R 230 at 245; SCF Finance Co Ltd v Masri (No 3) [1987] QB 1028; [1987] 1 All ER 194Â ; Serrao v Noel (1885) 15 QBD 549Â ; Rahme v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (NSWCA, Priestley, MeagherÂ JJA, Hope AJA, 20 December 1991, unreported, BC9101300).

The principle is not limited to cases where inconsistent judgments might result, but extends to potentially include any case where there has been an unreasonable failure to raise matters that might have constituted either a claim, defence or cross-claim in the earlier proceedings: Port of Melbourne Authority v Anshun , above; Manson v Vooght [1999] BPIR 376Â ; Vervaeke v Smith [1983] 1 AC 145 at 157 and 163; [1982] 2 All ER 144 at 152, 156Â (available divorce grounds not raised in earlier proceedings); Talbot v Berkshire County Council [1994] QB 290; [1993] 4 All ER 9Â (claim for damages barred where not included in earlier tortfeasor contribution proceedings); House of Spring Gardens Ltd v Waite [1991] 1 QB 241; [1990] 2 All ER 990Â (issued raised only by co-defendants in earlier proceedings); Bryant v Commonwealth Bank of Australia (1995) 57 FCR 287; 130 ALR 129Â (failure to raise a cross-claim). The principle can apply even where the party unsuccessfully attempted to raise the matter in earlier proceedings: Macquarie Bank Ltd v National Mutual Life Assn of Australasia Ltd (1996) 40 NSWLR 543; BC9605357Â . It can also apply in favour of a person who was not a party to the original proceedings: Yat Tung Investment Co Ltd v Dao Heng Bank Ltd , above, AC at 590; WLR at 696; Ashmore v British Coal Corp [1990] 2 QB 338; [1990] 2 All ER 981Â (earlier proceedings conducted as test cases); Johnson v Gore Wood and Co (a firm) , above (the test is the “degree of identification between the parties”).

Application of the principle requires consideration of two related questions. The first is whether the new matter is sufficiently closely related to the earlier proceedings that it could, and should, have been raised in them. The second is the reasonableness of the failure to raise the matter in the earlier proceedings. In answering the former consideration, the mere fact that the new matter is closely related to the earlier proceedings is not sufficient to give rise to an Anshun estoppel: Securum Finance Ltd v Ashton [2001] Ch 291 at [16]; [2000] 3 WLR 1400Â (earlier proceedings to recover under a guarantee do not preclude subsequent proceedings to enforce the guarantee security). In answering the second question, the court retains an overriding discretion to permit the later proceedings to continue unless it is satisfied that they constitute an abuse of process in all the circumstances: Johnson v Gore Wood and Co (a firm) , above (common understanding that later claim not included in compromise proceedings); Jetson (Estates) v Harvey [1983] 1 WLR 1401; [1984] 1 All ER 12Â (CA) (procedural defect in the first proceedings); Barrow v Bankside Agency Ltd [1996] 1 All ER 981; [1996] 1 WLR 257Â (later claim regarded as a true alternative claim); Ling v Commonwealth (1996) 68 FCR 180 at 190; 139 ALR 159Â (relevant criterion is the “reasonableness” of not raising the matter in the earlier proceedings, “special circumstances” not required).

The embarrassment caused by impermissible pleading is a general concept. The meaning of the concept is better captured by illustrative examples than precise definition: Bartlett v Swan Television & Radio Broadcasters Pty Ltd (1995) ATPR Â¶41-434; BC9501953Â . A pleading is embarrassing if it is unintelligible, ambiguous, or so imprecise in its identification of material factual allegations as to deprive the opposing party of proper notice of the real substance of the claim or defence: Gunns Ltd v Marr [2005] VSC 251; BC200505042 at [14]–[15]Â ; McGuirk v University of New South Wales [2009] NSWSC 1424; BC200911724Â atÂ [21]–[35]. A pleading may also be embarrassing if it contains inconsistent, confusing or irrelevant allegations: Shelton v National Roads & Motorists Assn Ltd (2004) 51 ACSR 278; [2004] FCA 1393; BC200407144 at [18]Â . Where a pleading contains vices of these kinds it is liable to be characterised as embarrassing even if it does contain material factual allegations sufficient to constitute a cause of action Northam v Favelle Favco Holdings Pty Ltd (NSWSC, BrysonÂ J, 7Â March 1995, BC9504276 at ppÂ 5–6).
Legislation cited in [14.28.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 CPA sÂ 56(1), ssÂ 57(1)(c), 60, CPA sÂ 91.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rÂ 4.15.

If the pleading defect can be cured by amendment, the court ought grant leave to amend rather than exercise the power to strike out: Republic of Peru v Peruvian Guano Co (1887) 36 Ch D 489 at 496Â ; Worthington & Co Ltd v Belton (1902) 18 TLR 438 at 439Â ; Wentworth v Rogers (No 5) (1986) 6 NSWLR 534 at 536Â . This discretionary approach is particularly appropriate where the plaintiff is a litigant in person: See Mann v Cahill (1999) 149 FLR 298; [1999] ACTSC 7; BC9900477Â . But whatever the status of the particular plaintiff, the practical reality is that an order granting leave to amend may be imposed on terms and will potentially permit the court to give directions most conducive to achieving the overriding purpose in CPA sÂ 56(1) . Conversely, striking out the pleading, even if followed by a formal order dismissing the proceedings, does not prevent a plaintiff from bringing further proceedings — having regard to the provisions of CPA sÂ 91 — and may not be the most efficient procedure for dealing with the substantive issues in dispute between the parties. Considerations of efficiency are relevant to the exercise of the discretion because of ssÂ 57(1)(c) and 60 of the CPA. As to striking out parts of documents other than pleadings, see rÂ 4.15 .

level.toc-caption: [14.28.30] Evidence in support of strike out applications

p.text: Legislation cited in [14.28.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 14.28(2).

heading.title: Evidence in support of strike out applications

p.text: The general principle that the power to strike out should be exercised only in plain and obvious cases precludes the court from an interim enquiry about the real merits of the plaintiff’s case: Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937Â ; Drummond-Jackson v British Medical Assn [1970] 1 All ER 1095; Wenlock v Moloney [1965] 2 All ER 871Â . It follows that the allegations in the impugned pleading will ordinarily be taken as accepted: Hubbuck & Sons Ltd v Wilkinson Heywood & Clark Ltd [1899] 1 QB 86Â ; Empire Shipping Co Inc v Owners of the Ship Shin Kobe Maru (1991) 32 FCR 78; 104 ALR 489Â ; Lonrho plc v Fayed [1992] 1 AC 448Â ; Air Services Australia v Zarb (NSWCA, Priestley, Powell JJA and Rolfe AJA, 25 August 1998, unreported, BC9804215); Northern Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Services Inc v Bradley (2000) 136 NTR 1; [2000] NTCA 13; BC200006939Â , and the court may make an order under the present rule merely on an examination of the pleadings: Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050Â ; Goodson v Grierson [1908] 1 KB 761Â ; Tampion v Anderson [1973] VR 321 at 325Â ). Although r 14.28(2) specifically permits the court to receive evidence on an application under this rule, that evidence must go to the issue of whether the pleading falls within r 14.28(1), rather than merely to the factual basis for the allegation. The distinction between evidence that is admissible and that which is inadmissible on such an application is difficult to express more precisely than that general statement. But it may be illustrated by reference to a number of categories of potentially admissible evidence, such as:

evidence for the purpose of explaining the allegations contained in the pleading: Rainy v Bravo (1872) LR 4 PC 287 at 296–7; Dougherty v Nationwide News Pty Ltd (1968) 88 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 146 at 149–51Â ; Day v William Hill (Park Lane) Ltd [1949] 1 KB 632; [1949] 1 All ER 219 at 221Â ; or

evidence to demonstrate that the plaintiff’s case is hopeless: Willis v Earl Howe [1893] 2 Ch 545Â ; Peter Kent Development Pty Ltd v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (NSWSC, Hunt J, 6Â May 1980, unreported); or

evidence to demonstrate that the allegations or non-admissions in pleadings are inconsistent with prior admissions made by the pleading party: Remmington v Scoles [1897] 2 Ch 1 at 7Â ; Finneran v Eyre (1893) 9 WN (NSW) 148Â ; Saffron v FCT (1991) 30 FCR 578; 102 ALR 19Â (appeal against income tax assessment raising factual issues inconsistent with a prior conviction); or
evidence to demonstrate conclusively the falsity of the matters pleaded: Pacific Acceptance Corp Ltd v Thompson [1963] NSWR 56Â ; or

evidence to demonstrate other reasons why the pleaded claim cannot succeed: Ruffıno v Grace Bros Pty Ltd [1980] 1 NSWLR 732Â (suit stayed where the plaintiff had already executed judgment against another joint tortfeasor). The court clearly has power to strike out even though the pleading itself discloses no defect as to form: Burton v Shire of Bairnsdale (1908) 7 CLR 76; 14 ALR 529; [1908] HCA 57Â ; Lawrance v Lord Norreys (1890) 15 App Cas 210 at 219; [1886] All ER Rep 858Â ; Howden v Truth & Sportsman Ltd (1937) 58 CLR 416Â .

level.toc-caption: [14.28.35] Examples illustrating use of the power to strike out

heading.title: Examples illustrating use of the power to strike out

p.text: It is virtually impossible to detail all the sorts of pleadings which might be dealt with under this rule, but the following instances provide examples that illustrate the potential application of the rule:

proceedings where the pleadings have been framed solely for the purpose of delay or in bad faith: Commercial Banking Co of Sydney Ltd v Worrall (1917) 35 WN (NSW) 5Â ; Creed v Smith [1914] VLR 652; (1914) 21 ALR 8Â (plaintiff not intending to prosecute the proceedings); Moriarty v London Chatham and Dover Railway Co (1870) LR 5 QB 314 (plaintiff admitting absence of a cause of action);

proceedings where the pleading is ambiguous or does not disclose a cause of action: Moore Road Machinery (NSW) Pty Ltd v Sourry [1960] NSWR 227; (1960) 77 WN (NSW) 554Â ; Peek Frean (Aust) Pty Ltd v IBM Australia Pty Ltd [1966] 1 NSWR 120; (1966) 83 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 467Â ; Leslie v Mirror Newspapers Ltd [1970] 1 NSWR 707; (1969) 91 WN (NSW) 648Â ; Moll v Butler (1985) 4 NSWLR 231; 10 Fam LR 544Â and Markisic v Commonwealth [2002] NSWSC 698; BC200204504Â ; (no claim lies against a judge of a superior court of record acting bona fide); Re Siromath Pty Ltd (No 3) (1991) 25 NSWLR 25; 9 ACLC 1587Â (no claim against a liquidator or court-appointed receiver except with the leave of the court); Attorney-General (NSW) v Agarsky (1986) 6 NSWLR 38Â ; Gallo v Dawson (1988) 82 ALR 401; 63 ALJR 121; BC8802631Â ;

proceedings where the claim cannot succeed: Australian Federation of Islamic Councils Inc v Westpac Banking Corp (1988) 17 NSWLR 623Â (proceedings brought against a person entitled to diplomatic immunity); Galaxy Communications Pty Ltd v Paramount Films of Australia Inc (NSWCA, Priestley, Meagher and Stein JJA, 27 March 1998, unreported, BC9800925) (cause of action dependent on happening of uncertain future event); Transocean Capital Pty Ltd v AFSIG Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 806; BC200606178Â (untenable allegation that moneys paid for alloted shares were held on trust);
a defence which must inevitably fail may also be struck out: Gatward v Kleem (1955) 72 WN (NSW) 354Â ;

proceedings where a substantive and effective limitation defence has been pleaded: Van Win Pty Ltd v Eleventh Mirontron Pty Ltd [1986] VR 484 at 487Â (procedural limitation provision — no defence filed — claim not struck out); Palmdale Insurance Ltd (in liq) v L Grollo & Co Pty Ltd [1986] VR 408Â (to the same effect at Mirontron, above); note however that these cases relate to limitation provisions which are procedural only and the English decisions in Ronex Properties Ltd v John Laing Constructions Ltd [1983] 1 QB 398 at 404 and Riches v DPP [1973] 1 WLR 1019Â are to the contrary): see also Dismore v Milton [1938] 3 All ER 762Â .

level.toc-caption: [14.28.40] No reasonable cause of action — questions of fact

heading.title: No reasonable cause of action — questions of fact

p.text: The power to strike out pleadings because they disclose no reasonable cause of action should be exercised only in plain and obvious cases: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Co-ownership Land Development Pty Ltd v Queensland Estates Pty Ltd (1973) 1 ALR 201; 47 ALJR 519Â ; Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937Â ; Hubbuck & Sons Ltd v Wilkinson Heywood & Clark Ltd [1899] 1 QB 86 at 91Â ; Moore v Lawson (1915) 31 TLR 418 at 419Â ; Attorney-General (Duchy of Lancaster) v London & North Western Railway Co [1892] 3 Ch 274 at 277Â ; Mayor of London v Horner (1914) 111 LT 512 at 514; Kellaway v Bury (1892) 66 LT 599 at 602Â ; Hill v Scott (1892) 8 WN (NSW) 98 at 99; Air Services Australia v Zarb (NSWCA, Priestley, Powell JJA and Rolfe AJA, 26 August 1998, unreported, BC9804215); Mills v Central Sydney Area Health Service [2002] NSWSC 728; BC200204850Â . A case is not “plain and obvious” and the power to strike out should generally not be exercised where there is a real issue to be tried, whether it is one of fact or law: Dyson v A-G [1911] 1 KB 410; [1912] 1 Ch 158Â ; Burton v Shire of Bairnsdale (1908) 7 CLR 76; 14 ALR 529; [1908] HCA 57Â ; Bayne v Baillieu (1908) 6 CLR 382 at 396; 14 ALR 426Â ; Dey v Victorian Railway Cmrs (1949) 78 CLR 62 at 91; [1949] ALR 333; BC4900050Â ; Woods v Wilson (1902) 19 WN (NSW) 147 at 148Â ; Commonwealth vÂ Griffiths (2007) 70 NSWLR 268; 245 ALR 172; [2007] NSWCA 370; BC200710981 atÂ [11], [12]Â BeazleyÂ JA, MasonÂ P concurring; Ion vÂ Danutz [2012] NSWSC 941; BC201206965Â . Although the emphasis on identifying a “real issue” does not in terms confine the strike out power to cases where there is no dispute of fact:Cox v Journeaux (No 2) (1935) 52 CLR 713 at 720; 9 ALJR 127Â ; that is the practical effect. Neither the apparent falsity or improbability of impugned allegations justifies the exercise of the power — because any attempt to investigate those matters would involve premature, and potentially unfair, trial of the proceedings: Remmington v Scoles [1897] 2 Ch 1 at 7Â . Indeed, there are numerous warnings in the authorities against entertaining strike-out applications where they involve a preliminary and necessarily inconclusive investigation of the facts on which the claim is based: X (Minors) v Bedfordshire County Council [1995] 2AC 633 at 740–1; Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552 at 577; 173 ALR 665 at 682; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311Â (conventional, but inadequate, form of pleading in a negligence action).

level.toc-caption: [14.28.45] No reasonable cause of action — questions of law

heading.title: No reasonable cause of action — questions of law

p.text: In an appropriate case the court may determine a difficult question of law on such an application even where it involves extensive argument: General Steel Industries Inc v Cmr for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125 at 130; [1965] ALR 636; BC6400590Â ; Mathaman v Nabalco Pty Ltd (1969) 14 FLR 10Â ; Gatward v Kleem (1955) 72 WN (NSW) 354Â ; Williams and Humbert Ltd v W & H Trade Marks (Jersey) Ltd [1986] AC 368; 1 All ER 129Â . See also McHarg v Woods Radio Pty Ltd [1948] VLR 496 at 498Â ; Co-ownership Land Development Pty Ltd v Queensland Estates Pty Ltd (1973) 1 ALR 201; 47 ALJR 519Â ; Elna Australia Pty Ltd v International Computers (Aust) Pty Ltd (No 2) (1987) 16 FCR 410; 75 ALR 271Â ; Mills v Central Sydney Area Health Service , above; Young v Waterways Authority of NSW [2000] NSWSC 612; BC200203758Â . But embarking upon this kind of an investigation on a strike out application requires the court to be satisfied that doing so will either avoid the need for, or substantially reduce the scope of, a subsequent trial: Williams and Humbert Ltd v W & H Trade Marks (Jersey) Ltd [1986] AC 368 at 436; 1 All ER 129Â ; Sun Earth Homes Pty Ltd v Australian Broadcasting Commission (1993) 45 FCR 265Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 14.29] r 14.29 Defence of extinction of right or title (cf SCR Part 5, ruleÂ 5B)

leg:heading.title: Defence of extinction of right or title (cf SCR Part 5, ruleÂ 5B)

p.text: For the purposes of section 68A of the Limitation Act 1969, a claim by the defendant that a right or title has been extinguished under Division 1 of Part 4 of that Act may be made by affidavit or by notice.
